newsitem.title: INDIA: India call slips, gilts volume sharply up on NSE.
newsitem.headline: India call slips, gilts volume sharply up on NSE.

text.p: Indian call money rates plummeted to 3.50-4.00 percent at close of trading on Tuesday, down from the day's opening of 5.00-6.00 percent, dealers said.
"Call rates opened at 6.00 percent and came down sharply to 4.0-5.0 percent," Shreepad Javadekar, dealer-in-charge at the Discount and Finance House of India said.
"Lenders are weak and borrowers are now strong -- they (borrowers) are now dectating the terms," Javadekar said.
"Call rates are expected to see a downward trend for the rest of the fortnight," Deepak Koyande, dealer at Mukesh Babu Securities in Bombay, said.
The 11.64 percent 2000 stock and 11.75 percent 2001 stock were among the most actively traded securities, with a combined volume of 1.25 billion rupees, Koyande said.
He said the total volume on the National Stock Exchange (NSE) touched a high of 4.50 billion rupees against Monday's 3.65 billion rupees.
Treasury bills maturing in October 1997 were traded at 11.32 percent, 30 basis points down from Monday's yield, dealers said.

Commercial papers were quoted at 12.00-12.75 percent for P1+ rated companies for 91 days. Inter-corporate deposits were quoted at 17-18.5 percent for 90 days for P1+ companies, while the P1 companies were quoted in the region of 21-27 percent.
